item.title: Installing Node.js for the Documentation Site
item.description:
Introduction

This guide describes how to properly set up Node.js in a Hugo+Docsy-based documentation project. The instructions are based on a real debugging and configuration experience during the deployment of a multilingual documentation site.

Why Node.js is Needed

The Docsy theme uses PostCSS to process stylesheets. This requires Node.js and related dependencies to be installed and correctly configured. Without them, running hugo results in errors like:

ERROR POSTCSS: failed to transform "/scss/main.css" (text/css): ...
Error [ERR_MODULE_NOT_FOUND]: Cannot find package 'stream' imported from ...

Initial Issue and Rollback to Node.js v18

While Node.js v22 is the current LTS, initial testing with PostCSS in the project using v22 resulted in compatibility issues. Specifically, the package postcss-cli attempted to use the stream module, which wasn’t polyfilled by default, leading to build failure.

item.title: Deploying the site on Netlify
item.description:
Step 1: Preparing the repositories

  1. Make sure your Hugo site code is hosted in a GitHub repository.
  2. The public repository should only contain generated files (e.g., from the public/ directory).

Step 2: Create a new project on Netlify

  1. Go to Netlify and sign up or log in.
  2. Click on the “New Site from Git” button.
  3. Connect your GitHub account with Netlify and select the appropriate repository.
  4. In the settings, specify the build command: hugo and the publish directory: public.

Step 3: Environment variables

Add environment variables if needed (e.g., for API keys or other settings).
